One famous painting that is known for its use of spots of color is "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte" by Georges Seurat.

This painting, which was completed in 1886, is an example of pointillism, a painting technique that uses small, distinct dots of color that are applied in patterns to form an image.

In "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte," Seurat used spots of color to create a highly detailed and intricate scene of a park on the banks of the Seine River in Paris. The painting features numerous figures, trees, boats, and buildings, all created through the careful application of tiny dots of color.

The spots of color in the painting serve to create texture, depth, and visual interest, as well as to guide the viewer's eye through the composition. The overall effect is one of vibrant energy and movement, despite the static nature of the scene depicted.

Seurat's use of spots of color in "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte" is considered a landmark achievement in the development of modern art, and the painting is now regarded as one of the masterpieces of the late 19th century.
